flowchart::>Aanvalsplan: Storing -> Melding. Melding compleet? (Diamond). If no, then informatie verzamelen (Rectangle), which loops back to Melding. If yes, then technisch? (Diamond). If no, then installatie vertrouwd? (Diamond). If no, then informatie verzamelen (Rectangle), which loops back to Melding. If yes (from installatie vertrouwd), or if yes (from technisch), proceeds to Diagnose section. Diagnose section starts with 1 van de 3 P's? (Diamond). If ja, then proces instelling? (Diamond). If nee, then buiten installatie (Rectangle), which loops back to Storing. If ja (from proces instelling), then Oplossen (Rectangle). If nee (from 1 van de 3 P's), then 1 keten? (Diamond). If nee, then ketens uitsluiten (Rectangle), which loops back to 1 keten. If ja, then 1 onderdeel? (Diamond). If nee, then onderdelen uitsluiten (Rectangle), which loops back to 1 onderdeel. If ja, then Oplossen (Rectangle). The chart also has a vertical label "Informeren" on the right side of the blue section and "Diagnose" on the left side of the orange section. The logo at the bottom right is ROVC Technisch de beste opleider. Figuur 2 SMIDO-aanvalsplan gestructureerd storingzoeken

koeltechniek1. Refrigerant exits the expansion valve at -5°C, 1.4 bar (blue pipe).2. It flows through the evaporator (bottom coil with fans), absorbing heat. At the evaporator outlet, the refrigerant is -5°C, 1.4 bar (blue pipe).3. After the evaporator, the refrigerant (R134a) is at 5°C. It then enters a component (possibly an accumulator) and exits at 0°C, 1.4 bar (light blue pipe), flowing into the compressor.4. The compressor increases the pressure and temperature of the refrigerant. Refrigerant exits the compressor at 55°C, 9 bar (red pipe).5. It flows through the condenser (top coil with fans), releasing heat. At the condenser outlet, the refrigerant is 40°C, 9 bar (red pipe).6. The refrigerant then flows to the expansion valve, entering it at 35°C, 9 bar (yellow pipe).The cycle then repeats from point 1.

Toegevoegde energie (warmte) A cooling installation diagram shows a closed loop. At the top, a compressor/pump is fed by "Toegevoegde energie (warmte)" (added energy/heat). From the compressor, a high-pressure gas line passes by a pressure gauge (P) and a thermometer (T), both labeled "hoog" (high) and "gas". This line leads to a condenser (left side), which includes a fan. Below the condenser, blue arrows indicate "Warmteafvoer buiten de koelkast" (heat dissipation outside the refrigerator). From the condenser, a high-pressure liquid line passes a pressure gauge (P) labeled "hoog" and "vloeistof" (liquid), then goes through an expansion valve. After the expansion valve, a low-pressure mixture of liquid and gas passes a pressure gauge (P) labeled "laag" (low) and "vloeistof/gas". This then enters an evaporator (right side), enclosed in a dashed box, which also includes a fan. Below the evaporator, a red arrow points up, indicating "Warmte toevoer in de koelkast" (heat supply in the refrigerator). The low-pressure gas exits the evaporator, passing a pressure gauge (P) and a thermometer (T), both labeled "laag" and "gas", before returning to the compressor.::> Warmteafvoer buiten de koelkast Warmte toevoer in de koelkast Figuur 4 Schematisch weergave koelinstallatie

<::A diagram illustrating a heat pump system. The main components are labeled A, B, C, and D. At the top, there's a label "Toegevoegde energie (warmte)" (Added energy (heat)) with a red arrow pointing down towards component C. Component C is a compressor. The input line to C (coming from A) has pressure gauge P and temperature gauge T both labeled "laag" (low), indicating "gas" state. The output line from C (going to D) has pressure gauge P and temperature gauge T both labeled "hoog" (high), indicating "gas" state. Component D is a heat exchanger with a fan, labeled 'D'. It receives high pressure, high temperature gas from C. The output from D is labeled "vloeistof" (liquid). Below D, blue arrows point downwards, indicating "Warmteafvoer buiten de warmtepomp" (Heat discharge outside the heat pump). Component B is an expansion valve. It receives "vloeistof" (liquid) from D. Before B, there is a pressure gauge P labeled "hoog" (high). After B, the output is labeled "vloeistof/gas" (liquid/gas mixture), and there is a pressure gauge P labeled "laag" (low). Component A is a heat exchanger with a fan, labeled 'A'. It receives "vloeistof/gas" from B. The output from A is labeled "gas". Below A, black arrows point upwards, and a red arrow points upwards with the label "Warmte toevoer in de warmtepomp" (Heat supply into the heat pump). Component A and the heat supply are enclosed by a dashed box. The overall cycle shows: Warmte toevoer in de warmtepomp (A) -> Compressor (C) -> Warmteafvoer buiten de warmtepomp (D) -> Expansion valve (B) -> Warmte toevoer in de warmtepomp (A). Figuur 1

This diagram illustrates a demo cooling installation (koelen). The system consists of two main loops, likely a refrigeration cycle and a secondary fluid loop, interconnected by a heat exchanger. **Refrigeration Cycle (Black, Green, Blue, Red Lines):** - **Evaporator (E1):** A component with a fan, receiving refrigerant. Temperature sensor TT (T1) is located at its outlet. - **Suction Line:** From E1, a line with pressure sensor PT and temperature sensor TT leads to a compressor. - **Compressor (A1):** A compressor unit with associated sensors: TT (T3), PZH (pressure switch high), PSL (pressure switch low), PI (pressure indicator), and TT (T2). - **Heat Exchanger (H):** A plate-type heat exchanger where the refrigerant (red line input, blue line output) exchanges heat with another fluid (red/blue arrows indicating flow). - **Condenser (B1):** A component with a fan, receiving refrigerant from the heat exchanger. Temperature sensor TT (T4) is at its outlet. - **Liquid Line:** From B1, the refrigerant flows through check valve N1. - **Receiver (D):** A cylindrical tank labeled "0,7 Ltr." for liquid refrigerant storage, connected via valves V1 and V2. - **Filter (C):** A filter component in the liquid line. - **Expansion Device:** A valve controlled by a temperature controller TCE with sensor TT (T5), located before the evaporator E1, indicated by a dashed control line. **Ancillary Components:** - **Valves:** V1, V2, V3, V4 are manual or solenoid valves controlling flow. - **Gauges:** G1 and G2 are pressure gauges/indicators. - **Sight Glass/Filter (F):** A component in the liquid line, possibly a sight glass or filter. - **Check Valves:** N1 and N2. - **Temperature Controller (TC):** A controller near valve V3. **Flow Paths:** - The refrigerant cycle is depicted with black lines for high-pressure vapor, red lines for high-pressure liquid/vapor, blue lines for low-pressure liquid/vapor, and green lines for intermediate stages, often indicating a liquid line. - The heat exchanger H has separate red and blue lines indicating a secondary fluid loop, possibly for heating or cooling a process fluid. **Overall Operation:** The diagram illustrates a typical vapor-compression refrigeration cycle modified with a heat exchanger, likely for heat recovery or a specific application where both cooling and heating are involved. The caption indicates it's a demo cooling installation.::> Koelen Figuur 3 Schema van demo-koelinstallatie (koelen)

Opgaven bij het schema- H: Evaporator (blue coiled heat exchanger) with connections C0 and C1.- I: Condenser (red coiled heat exchanger) with connection M2.- S: Compressor, connected to C2 on the suction side and M1 on the discharge side.- F: Thermostatic Expansion Valve (TEV).- L: Liquid receiver.- E: Filter drier.- D: Sight glass or liquid indicator.- K: Control unit with labels LD (Low Discharge) and HD (High Discharge), connected to the compressor discharge line and M2.- R: Condenser fan unit, connected after the condenser I.- G: Shut-off valve.Pressure gauges (PI) are labeled A and B. A pressure control (PC) is labeled P.Flow path:- The compressor (S) draws refrigerant from C2 (evaporator outlet) and discharges to M1.- M1 connects to K, then to M2.- M2 feeds the condenser (I).- From condenser (I), refrigerant goes to the condenser fan unit (R).- From R, it passes through pressure control P and enters the liquid receiver (L).- From L, the refrigerant flows through O, then filter drier (E), then valve (G), and then sight glass (D).- From D, it passes through the thermostatic expansion valve (F).- The expanded refrigerant enters the evaporator (H) at C0.- From evaporator (H), it exits at C1, which loops back to M2 and also connects to C0, eventually returning to the compressor (S) via C2.Pressure gauge A is connected to the line before the TEV (F). Pressure gauge B is connected to the line after the sight glass (D) and before the TEV (F).Figuur 3 Schema glazenmodel7. Wat is in het schema de verdamper?8. Wat is in dit schema de condensor?9. Wat is in dit schema het expansieorgaan?

Koelkringloop-proces - H: An evaporator, depicted as blue coils, connected to points C0 and C1. - I: A condenser, depicted as red coils, connected to point M2. - S: A compressor, located at the bottom left, with connections C2 and M1. - A: A pressure indicator (PI) on the line between the compressor (S) and the evaporator (H). - F: A thermostatic expansion valve (TEV) on the line between the compressor (S) and the evaporator (H). - B: A pressure indicator (PI) on the line between the compressor (S) and the condenser (I). - K: A control unit or component with connections labeled LD (Low Differential) and HD (High Differential), situated on the line from the compressor to the condenser. - R: A fan/heat exchanger unit, positioned after the condenser (I). - P: A pressure control (PC) sensor, located after the fan/heat exchanger (R). - L: A receiver tank, positioned after the pressure control (P). - O: A pipe connecting the receiver (L) to a filter. - E: A filter/drier unit. - G: A valve. - D: A sight glass, located before the thermostatic expansion valve (F). The refrigerant flows from the compressor (S) to the condenser (I), then through the receiver (L), filter (E), valve (G), sight glass (D), and expansion valve (F) to the evaporator (H), and finally back to the compressor (S). Figuur 4 Schema glazenmodel::>

The image displays a refrigeration cycle (koelkringloop) with its main components and the corresponding P-h diagram. The cycle starts from the evaporator (bottom, blue tubing with internal arrows indicating flow to the right), where the refrigerant absorbs heat, represented by fans blowing over the coils. The refrigerant then flows as a low-pressure vapor (light blue pipe) to the compressor (right, green and red engine-like component with a piston). From the compressor, the high-pressure, high-temperature vapor (red pipe with arrows indicating flow upwards and to the left) moves to the condenser (top, red tubing with internal arrows indicating flow to the left), where it releases heat to the surroundings, again represented by fans. After condensing, the high-pressure liquid refrigerant (yellow pipe with arrows indicating flow to the left and downwards) goes to the expansion valve (left, a mechanical component with yellow and dark blue inlets/outlets). The expansion valve reduces the pressure and temperature of the refrigerant (dark blue pipe with arrows indicating flow to the right), which then returns to the evaporator to complete the cycle. The diagram also includes numbered boxes at various points in the cycle: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, which likely denote specific states or measurement points. In the center of the diagram, a P-h (Pressure-enthalpy) chart illustrates the thermodynamic states of the refrigerant throughout the cycle, showing a typical refrigeration cycle loop within the saturation dome, with pressure (P) on the y-axis and enthalpy (h) on the x-axis. Figuur 9 De koelkringloop::>

A phase diagram for water at 1 bar absolute pressure. The vertical axis is 'Temperatuur' (Temperature) in °C, and the horizontal axis is 'Warmtetoevoer' (Heat supply). The graph shows four points labeled A, B, C, and D. Point A is at 0 °C. From A to B, the temperature increases from 0 °C to 100 °C, representing the heating of liquid water. This section is associated with 'Verwarmen van de vloeistof' (Heating of the liquid). Point B is at 100 °C. From B to C, the temperature remains constant at 100 °C while heat is added, indicating the 'Verdampingsproces' (Evaporation process) where water changes from liquid to vapor. Point C is at 100 °C. From C to D, the temperature of the vapor increases above 100 °C. This section is associated with 'Verwarmen van de damp' (Heating of the vapor). The diagram specifies 'H₂O (water)' and 'Druk = 1 bara'.::>Figuur 14 Verdampingsproces van water

A graph titled "Condensatieproces van water" (Condensation process of water) shows temperature versus heat dissipation. The y-axis is labeled "Temperatuur" (Temperature) with values 0 °C and 100 °C. The x-axis is labeled "Warmteafvoer" (Heat dissipation). The graph shows a process from point A to D. From point A (0 °C) to B (100 °C), there is an upward sloping line representing the heating of water, indicated by a gradient arrow. From point B to C (both at 100 °C), there is a horizontal line labeled "Condensatieproces" (Condensation process), representing the phase change from vapor to liquid at a constant temperature. This segment is also labeled on the right as "Condensatie van de vloeistof" (Condensation of the liquid). From point C to D, there is an upward sloping line representing the cooling of the vapor. This segment is labeled on the right as "Afkoelen van de damp" (Cooling of the vapor). In the top right corner, a box contains the text "H₂O (water)" and "Druk = 1 barᵃ" (Pressure = 1 barᵃ).::>

The y-axis is labeled "Temperatuur °C" with tick marks at 100, 0, -26, -30, -33, -34, -41, -46, -48, and -53. The x-axis is labeled "Warmte-inhoud kJ/kg". Multiple lines represent different substances, each showing an initial increase in temperature with heat content, followed by a plateau (indicating phase change), and then a further increase in temperature. The legend identifies the substances and their corresponding line styles/colors: Water/stoom (solid light blue line), R-134a (solid purple line), R-1234yf (dashed teal line), NH3 (solid yellow line), R-407C (solid dark blue line), R404a (dashed orange line), R-507 (solid red line), and R-32 (solid brown line).::>

refrigeration cycle::>A diagram illustrating a refrigeration cycle with components including a compressor, condenser, expansion valve, and evaporator, showing the flow of refrigerant and its conditions at various points.The cycle begins with the compressor on the right. Hot, high-pressure gas exits the compressor and flows into the condenser (top, red pipes). In the condenser, the refrigerant cools and condenses. At point 4, the temperature is 55°C and pressure is 9 bar. At point 5, after some cooling, the refrigerant is at 40°C and 9 bar. The section between point 5 and point 6 is labeled "Onderkoeling vloeistof" (Subcooling liquid), where the refrigerant is further cooled to 35°C at 9 bar (point 6), indicating it is subcooled liquid.From point 6, the subcooled liquid refrigerant flows through a yellow pipe to the expansion valve (left side). After passing through the expansion valve, the refrigerant's temperature and pressure drop significantly.At point 1, the refrigerant is at -5°C and 1.4 bar. It then enters the evaporator (bottom, blue pipes). In the evaporator, the refrigerant absorbs heat and evaporates. At point 2, the refrigerant is still at -5°C and 1.4 bar. The section between point 2 and point 3 is labeled "Oververhitting zuiggas" (Superheating suction gas), indicating the refrigerant becomes superheated vapor. At point 3, the refrigerant is at 0°C and 1.4 bar. An additional label near point 3 indicates "5°C R134a", possibly representing the superheated suction gas temperature entering the compressor, with R134a being the refrigerant type. The superheated gas then returns to the compressor to complete the cycle. The flow direction is indicated by arrows throughout the pipes.Figuur 19 Oververhitting zuiggas en onderkoeling vloeistof

Point 1: -5°C, 1.4 bar; Point 2: -5°C, 1.4 bar; Point 3: 0°C, 1.4 bar, R134a; Point 4: 80°C, 9 bar; Point 5: 40°C, 9 bar; Point 6: 35°C, 9 bar. In the top right corner are standard window controls: volume, minimize, and close buttons.

The region to the right of the curve is labeled 'oververhit gas' (superheated gas). An arrow points to the left side of the curve, labeled 'vloeistoflijn' (liquid line). An arrow points to the right side of the curve, labeled 'verzadigde damplijn' (saturated vapor line).Figure 21 Basisindeling h log p-diagram::>

Expanderen en comprimeren <::p-h diagram showing compression and expansion processes : chart::> Figuur 24 Compressie en expansie The chart displays a pressure-enthalpy (p-h) diagram. The y-axis represents pressure (p) and the x-axis represents enthalpy (h) in kJ/kg. A saturation dome is depicted by a thick black curve. Inside the dome, there are two vertical lines representing isotherms: Tv (blue line) and Tc (red line). Two horizontal dashed lines represent isobars: pc (red) and pv (blue). Key points and processes indicated: - The Tv isotherm intersects the x-axis at approximately 200 kJ/kg and a point within the dome at approximately 397 kJ/kg. - The Tc isotherm intersects the x-axis at approximately 241 kJ/kg and a point within the dome at approximately 413 kJ/kg. - A dashed arrow points downwards from the intersection of the Tc isotherm and the pc isobar to the pv isobar, indicating a process from higher pressure/temperature to lower pressure. - On the right side of the dome, a red curve extends downwards to h = 418 kJ/kg. - Another dashed arrow points upwards from a point on the pv isobar within the dome to the red curve on the right, indicating a process from lower pressure to higher enthalpy. <::>

1. A compressor (labeled '1' in a circle) receives 'vloeistof/gas' at 1.9 barᵉ (indicated by pressure sensor P). It is driven by 'Toegevoegde energie (warmte)'.2. The compressor outputs high-pressure 'gas' which passes a pressure sensor P and a temperature sensor T (labeled '4') reading 6.7 barᵉ and 43°C.3. This high-pressure gas then enters a condenser (labeled '5', depicted as a heat exchanger with a fan inside). The condenser has an internal temperature of +30°C and facilitates 'Warmteafvoer naar omgeving +15°C' (heat dissipation to ambient +15°C).4. The refrigerant exits the condenser as 'vloeistof' (liquid) and passes a temperature sensor T and a pressure sensor P (labeled '6') reading 25°C and 6.7 barᵉ.5. The liquid then passes through an expansion device (not explicitly numbered but implied in the circuit).6. After expansion, the refrigerant (now 'gas') passes a pressure sensor P and a temperature sensor T (labeled '3') reading 1.9 barᵉ and +5°C.7. This low-pressure refrigerant then enters an evaporator (labeled '2', depicted as a heat exchanger with a fan inside, enclosed in a dashed box representing 'Ruimte +8°C'). The evaporator has an internal temperature of -0°C and receives 'Warmtetoevoer' (heat supply).8. The refrigerant exits the evaporator and returns to the compressor, completing the cycle.Figuur 25 Meetwaarden bij een koelinstallatie

The refrigeration cycle is depicted by a series of numbered points and colored arrows: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. The cycle starts from point 1 at 2.9 bara, moves horizontally to point 2 (evaporation), then follows an angled path (compression) through point 3 to point 4 at 43°C and 7.7 bara. From point 4, it moves horizontally to point 5 (condensation) at 7.7 bara, then vertically downwards to point 6 (subcooling/expansion), and finally vertically from point 6 back to point 1 (expansion/throttling) at 2.9 bara. The arrows indicate the direction of the cycle: green arrows for evaporation (1 to 2), compression (2 to 6, then to 5, then to 4), and expansion (6 to 1); red arrows for condensation (4 to 5). The path from point 2 to 6 is a vertical line up to the 7.7 bara line, then horizontally to point 5, then point 4. There's a vertical line from point 6 down to point 1. The sequence of processes appears to be: evaporation (1-2), compression (2-3-4), condensation (4-5), expansion/subcooling (5-6), and throttling (6-1). <::A diagram titled "Koelinstallatie met hulpcomponenten" (Refrigeration installation with auxiliary components) shows the components of a refrigeration system arranged in a cycle with red arrows indicating the flow. The cycle begins with a compressor, which leads to a hogedrukbeveiliging (high-pressure protection device). From there, the flow goes to a condensor (condenser), then to a vloeistofreservoir (liquid reservoir). Next in the cycle is a filter-droger (filter-dryer), followed by a vloeistof kijkglas (liquid sight glass), and then an elektromagneet afsluiter (solenoid valve). The flow continues to an expansieorgaan (expansion device), which leads to a verdamper (evaporator). Finally, the verdamper connects to a lagedrukbeveiliging (low-pressure protection device), which returns the flow to the compressor, completing the cycle. Each unit consists of: * A compressor (1) with a fan symbol (2) for head cooling. * A high-pressure switch (PA H, labeled 3) connected to the discharge line of the compressor. * An oil differential pressure switch (PdA, labeled 4) connected to the compressor's oil system. * Inlet and outlet valves (Afsluiter) for the compressor. * An oil level regulator (12) connected to the compressor's oil sump.::> The discharge lines from the three compressors converge into a common horizontal pipe, which is the Persheader (discharge header) (5). From the oil separator (6), a line goes through an Afsluiter (shut-off valve) (7) and then connects to "naar condensor" (to condenser).::> Oil separated in the Olieafscheider (6) flows via two lines with Schräder ventiel (Schrader valves) (9) to an Oliebuffervat (oil buffer tank) (8). From the Oliebuffervat (8), oil flows through a Verschildrukklep (differential pressure valve) (PC, labeled 10) to a horizontal oil distribution line.::> This oil distribution line feeds the Olieniveau-regelaar (oil level regulator) (12) of each compressor unit. The Zuigheader (13) is connected to "van verdamper" (from evaporator). Before entering the Zuigheader (13) from the evaporator, there's a section with Isolatie type 32 mm (insulation type 32 mm) (14) and a Zuigfilter (suction filter) (15).::> A separate line originates from "van condensor" (from condenser) on the top left. This line goes through an Afsluiter (shut-off valve) and then to a Vloeistofreservoir (liquid receiver) (16). From the Vloeistofreservoir (16), the liquid passes through a Filterdroger (filter dryer) (17) and a Kijkglas (sight glass) (18) before connecting to the main suction line going to the evaporator (indicated by "van verdamper"). A branch from this line also goes to a control element (represented by a dashed circle with internal horizontal lines and an arrow, connected to the high/low pressure switch).::> A Gecombineerde HD/LD pressostaat (combined HP/LP pressure switch) (PA, labeled 19) is connected to both the high-pressure side (via an Afsluiter (20) and a Hoge druk aansluiting t.b.v. manometer (high pressure connection for manometer) (22)) and the low-pressure side (via an Afsluiter (20) and a Lage druk aansluiting t.b.v. manometer (low pressure connection for manometer) (21)).::> The overall diagram illustrates a complex refrigeration system with multiple stages of compression, oil management, and safety controls.:;>

a compressor (right, green/red), a condenser (top, red/yellow coils with a fan), an expansion valve (left, yellow/blue), and an evaporator (bottom, blue/light blue coils with a fan). Arrows indicate the direction of refrigerant flow, and color changes represent different states and temperatures. The cycle begins with the compressor (red/light blue) discharging high-pressure, high-temperature gaseous refrigerant (red pipe, point 4). This refrigerant flows to the condenser (top), where it releases heat (indicated by the fan) and condenses into a high-pressure liquid (yellow pipe, point 5). The liquid then passes through an expansion valve (left), where its pressure and temperature drop significantly (blue pipe, point 6). This low-pressure, low-temperature refrigerant then enters the evaporator (bottom), absorbs heat (indicated by the fan) and evaporates into a low-pressure gas (light blue pipe, point 1). This gaseous refrigerant then returns to the compressor to complete the cycle. Points 2 and 3 are also marked along the evaporator exit and inlet to the compressor respectively. The central P-h diagram plots pressure (P) against enthalpy (h), showing the thermodynamic states of the refrigerant throughout the cycle. It features a saturation dome and a closed loop connecting four colored points (red, yellow, light blue, blue) that correspond to the states of the refrigerant at different stages of the cycle, matching the colors used in the main diagram. The diagram illustrates the compression, condensation, expansion, and evaporation processes on the P-h chart.Figuur 4

A process and instrumentation diagram (P&ID) illustrating an indirect pressure-controlled evaporator pressure regulator within a refrigeration or HVAC system. The diagram shows two evaporator/condenser units, a compressor, a receiver tank, and several control valves and instruments. Starting from the left: 1. A rectangular unit with a fan and upward arrows (evaporator/condenser 1) receives flow from a lower line and outputs to a horizontal line. 2. On this horizontal line, there's a valve labeled "Verdamperdrukregelaar" (Evaporator Pressure Regulator). 3. In parallel to the "Verdamperdrukregelaar" valve, there's another valve controlled by a Pressure Controller (PC). The PC senses pressure from the line after the "Verdamperdrukregelaar" valve. 4. The combined flow from these valves proceeds to a compressor, represented by a circular symbol with a triangle inside. The compressor has two pressure indicators: PE-L (Low Pressure) and PE-H (High Pressure). 5. The output of the compressor goes to a second rectangular unit with a fan and downward arrows (evaporator/condenser 2). 6. The output of evaporator/condenser 2 flows into a receiver tank, depicted as an elongated horizontal oval. 7. From the receiver tank, a line leads to a valve controlled by a Temperature Controller (TC). 8. The output of the TC-controlled valve then connects back to the input line of the first evaporator/condenser unit, completing the loop. Figure 111 Indirect drukgestuurde verdamperdrukregelaar::>

Heetgasomloopregeling (Hot Gas Bypass Control). The diagram illustrates a refrigeration or heat pump system with a compressor, two heat exchangers (evaporator and condenser), and a receiver. From left to right: a heat exchanger unit with a fan and upward air arrows receives refrigerant. A line from this unit leads to the compressor. The compressor discharges hot gas to another heat exchanger unit with a fan and downward air arrows, which then feeds into a receiver (an elongated tank). From the receiver, the liquid refrigerant returns to the first heat exchanger. Control elements are integrated into the system: 1. A Pressure Controller (PC) labeled "Heetgasomloopklep" (Hot gas bypass valve) controls a valve on a bypass line that connects the compressor discharge directly to the suction line, bypassing the condenser and evaporator. 2. A Temperature Controller (TC) controls a valve on the liquid line before the evaporator. 3. Another Temperature Controller (TC) controls a valve on a line branching from the liquid line to the suction line, labeled "Zuiggaskoeling" (Suction gas cooling). ::> Figuur 2 Heetgasomloopregeling
